results.name: a(0)=1, a(1)=0, a(n) = a(n-1) + a(n-2) + Sum_{i=0...n-1} a(i).
comment: For the general recurrence X(n) = 3*X(n-1) - X(n-3) we get sum{k=3,..,n} X(k) = 3*sum{k=2,..,n-1} X(k) - sum{k=0,..,n-3} X(k), which implies the following summation formula: X(n) - X(n-1) - X(n-2) - X(2) + X(1) + X(0) = sum{k=2,..,n-1} X(k). Similarly from the formula X(n) + X(n-3) = 3*X(n-1) we deduce the following relations: sum{k=0,..,2*n-1} X(3*k) = 3*sum{k=0,..,n-1} X(6*k+2), sum{k=0,..,2*n-1} X(3*k+1) = 3*sum{k=1,..,n} X(6*k), and sum{k=0,..,2*n-1} X(3*k+2) = 3*sum{k=1,..,n} X(6*k-2). At last from the formula X(n)-X(n-1)=(X(n-1)-X(n-3))+X(n-1)

we obtain the relations: sum{k=2,..,2*n+1} (-1)^(k-1)*X(k) = X(2*n) - X(0) + sum{k=1,..,n} X(2*k) and sum{k=3,..,2n} (-1)^(k)*X(k) = X(2*n-1) - X(1) + sum{k=2,..,n} X(2*k-1). - Roman Witula, Aug 27 2012
formula: Proof of the above conjecture: we have a(n) - a(n-1) =

a(n-1) + a(n-2) + (a(0) + ... + a(n-1)) - a(n-2) - a(n-3) - (a(0) + ... + a(n-2)), which after simple algebra implies a(n) - a(n-1) = 2*a(n-1) - a(n-3), so the Mathar's formula holds true (see also Witula's comment above) - Roman Witula, Aug 27 2012
